summary: Authorities have imposed international travel restrictions from late February 2020 – one month after the first cases were detected in the country – and nationwide social distancing guidelines from late March 2020. The country has the highest case and fatality figures in the world. From March 2020, stay-at-home lockdown began to be implemented as the virus spread across the country. All states began reopening as of June 2020 at widely varying paces, before reimposing restrictions from October 2020, and then moving once more to lift most remaining measures as of April 2021 while implementing vaccination campaigns. Approximately 30,000 cases per day were reported nationwide as of early April.
hotspots: Alaska, Colorado, Texas, Kentucky, Virginia, North Carolina, New York, New Jersey, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts

areaRestrictions.text: American, United, Delta, Southwest, JetBlue, Allegiant, Hawaiian and Alaska Airlines have suspended hundreds of domestic flights due to COVID-19-related staff shortages.   The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced that domestic travellers who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, defined as two weeks having passed since obtaining their final dose of the vaccine, do not need to get tested before or after travel and do not need to self-quarantine. Domestic travellers are recommended to take a viral test 1-3 days before departure and to self-quarantine for 7 days upon arrival. Travellers should get tested again 3-5 days after arrival; if a test is not available or results are delayed, travellers should self-quarantine for a total of 10 days.

In areas where COVID-19 hospitalisations are high, non-urgent surgeries will be suspended and ambulance services will not be dispatched for non-life threatening emergencies. Long wait times are certain due to staff shortages at public and private healthcare providers nationwide.

transportation.text: International flights are subject to suspension on short notice in response to country-specific travel bans.

declarationDocuments.text:
Travel (PLF) document
All travellers aged two and older must complete an Attestation Form prior to departure. Proof of being fully vaccinated or exempt from this requirement is required for each noncitizen who is a nonimmigrant arriving or transiting by air, as well as via land ports of entry and ferry terminals. Further details can be found at (https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/fr-proof-negative-test.html)

entry.text: Air travellers over the age of two, who have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and present a negative COVID-19 test no older than 24 hours or proof of recovery no older than 90 days are allowed entry. Travellers via land ports of entry or ferry terminals, excluding US citizens, Lawful Permanent Residents and US nationals, are required to be fully vaccinated but no pre-travel testing is required. Face masks are no longer mandatory for the journey and travellers are required to share their telephone number and email address for contact tracing. An ongoing judicial review mey force the the measure to be reimposed.   Embassies and consulates have resumed routine visa services but have broad discretion to determine how to prioritize visa appointments among the range of visa classes as safely as possible, subject to local conditions and restrictions.

diseaseTesting.text: Before travel All passengers on inbound international flights, excluding from American Samoa, Guam and the Northern Marianas Islands, Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands, must present a negative COVID-19 test result not older than one day or medical documentation confirming that the traveller has contracted and recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days before boarding a flight to the US. An at-home NAAT or antigen SARS-CoV-2 viral test authorised by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) may be used for this requirement. Officials have imposed a one-day validity period for testing as a more flexible option than a strict 24 hours before departure time, meaning that a negative test obtained at any time on the day prior to travel will be valid. Foreign passengers must be fully vaccinated to enter the US. Children between the ages of 2 and 17 travelling with fully vaccinated parents or guardians are also subject to pre-departure testing requirements. Flight crews, maritime crews with valid visas, diplomats, military personnel and urgent humanitarian or medical cases, including travellers unable to procure a pre-departure test at their point of embarkation, are exempt. Fully vaccinated travellers via land ports of entry and ferry terminals are also exempt. A list of exemptions to testing is available at (https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/pdf/Global-Airline-Testing-Order-RPWSigned-Encrypted-p.pdf Global-Airline-Testing-Order-RPWSigned-Encrypted-p.pdf. All transit passengers on inbound international flights over the age of two must present a negative COVID-19 test result not older than 24 hours or medical documentation confirming that the traveller has contracted and recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days before boarding a flight to the US. Travellers arriving from American Samoa, Guam and the Northern Marianas Islands, Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands are exempt. An at-home NAAT or antigen SARS-CoV-2 viral test authorised by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) may be used for this requirement. Officials have imposed a one-day validity period for testing as a more flexible option than a strict 24 hours before departure time, meaning that a negative test obtained at any time on the day prior to travel will be valid.

quarantineModality.text: International travellers are not required to quarantine upon arrival. However, the CDC recommends that travellers who are not fully vaccinated stay home and self-quarantine for 7 days after arrival. All travellers should take a test again 3-5 days after arrival; if a test is not available or results are delayed, unvaccinated travellers are recommended to stay home and self-quarantine for a total of 10 days after travelling.

mask.text: Some states and territories require residents to wear masks in indoor public spaces. Violators may be subject to fines and be denied entry to businesses and use of public transport. Most states and territories have voluntary measures or measures restricted to specific venues and municipalities.   Enforcement varies widely and is not consistently enforced below the federal level. A mandate requiring travellers to wear a mask on inter-state transport, including at airports and onboard flights, trains, planes, intercity buses and ferries, was suspended on 18 April pending a judical review of its constitutionality. The rule was in place until 3 May before its suspension. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continues to recommend all travellers wear masks on airplanes, trains, buses and all other means of public transport.

exit.text: There are no exit restrictions though international travel to high-COVID-19 risk destinations is strongly discouraged.

diseaseVaccination.text: Non-resident inbound travellers over the age of 18 on non-essential business must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 with vaccines approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or World Health Organization (WHO).   Travellers on non-tourist visas (excludes B-1 and B-2) arriving from approximately 50 listed countries where less than 10 percent of the population is vaccinated due to the unavailability of vaccines will be permitted entry as humanitarian cases. The list is updated weekly at (https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/order-safe-travel/technical-instructions.html and https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/order-safe-travel/technical-instructions.html)
qualifiedVaccines: Vaxevria (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.

areaPolicy.text: Limited federal policies for quarantine and testing are in effect nationwide. Most policy decisions are implemented at the state, county and municipal level.

summary: Cities and provinces were quicker to impose restrictions after COVID-19 cases were first detected in January 2020. The curve of active cases has decreased since early June 2020, prompting many provinces to begin gradually easing COVID-19 measures before a second wave began in early 2021, triggering renewed provincial lockdowns. Measures were again relaxed before a third wave in winter 2021-2022 triggered curfews and other controls. A federal vaccine mandate is in effect for both domestic and international travel.

areaRestrictions.text: Greyhound Canada permanently shut down all services in Canada in May 2021. WestJet, Air Transat, Air Canada Rouge, Jazz Aviation and other carriers have cancelled dozens of domestic flights due to staffing issues. Proof of full vaccination or a medical exemption is required for air passengers, both domestic and international, as well cruise ship passengers and VIA Rail and Rocky Mountaineer trains. Entry to Quebec province"s Cree Territory of James Bay is at the discretion of Cree communities. Consult website (https://www.escapelikeneverbefore.com/en/useful-information/covid-19/ and https://www.escapelikeneverbefore.com/en/useful-information/covid-19/ for further details.) Consult website (https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/provinces and https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/provinces) for updated internal travel restrictions.

The closure of non-essential businesses, schools and public events differ by province and territory. All essential businesses remain open and public transport is operating. Further information on provincial COVID-19 regulations can be found at (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/provincial-territorial-resources-covid-19.html and https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/provincial-territorial-resources-covid-19.html) Covid Pass is required for some domestic activities: All passengers aged 12 and older boarding both domestic and international flights, VIA Rail and the Rocky Mountaineer trains or cruise ship voyages of more than 24 hours must provide provide a medical exemption or proof of full vaccination. Provinces and territories are permitted to require vaccine passports for entry to hospitality establishments, fitness centres, sporting events, personal care businesses, long-term care facilities and cultural and entertainment venues. Covid Pass availability: Alberta The Alberta immunization card is available at <(https://myhealth.alberta.ca/myhealthrecords)https://myhealth.alberta.ca/myhealthrecords. British Columbia The BC vaccine card is available at <(https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/vaccine/proof)https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/vaccine/proof. Manitoba The Manitoba vaccine card is available at <(https://www.manitobavaccine.ca/answers/will-there-be-a-vaccine-passport-or-proof-of-immunity-document/)https://www.manitobavaccine.ca/answers/will-there-be-a-vaccine-passport-or-proof-of-immunity-document/. New Brunswick The New Brunswick vaccine card is available at <(https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/nb-vaccine.html)https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/nb-vaccine.html. Newfoundland and Labrador The Newfoundland and Labrador vaccination passport is available at <(https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/vaccine/online-vaccination-records/)https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/vaccine/online-vaccination-records/. Northwest Territories The Northwest Territories (NWT) vaccine pass is available at <(https://www.gov.nt.ca/covid-19/en/proof-vaccination)https://www.gov.nt.ca/covid-19/en/proof-vaccination. Nova Scotia The Nova Scotia vaccine card is available at <(https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/proof-of-full-vaccination-policy/)https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/proof-of-full-vaccination-policy/. Ontario The Ontario vaccine receipt is available at <(https://covid-19.ontario.ca/covid-19-vaccine-booking-support#vaccination-receipts)https://covid-19.ontario.ca/covid-19-vaccine-booking-support#vaccination-receipts. Prince Edward Island The PEI Vax Pass is available at <(https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/topic/covid-19-vaccines)https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/topic/covid-19-vaccines. Quebec The Quebec vaccination passport is available at <(https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progress-of-the-covid-19-vaccination/covid-19-vaccination-passport)https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progress-of-the-covid-19-vaccination/covid-19-vaccination-passport. Saskatchewan The Saskatchewan vaccination passport is available at <(https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/health-care-administration-and-provider-resources/treatment-procedures-and-guidelines/emerging-public-health-issues/2019-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine/proof-of-vaccination)https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/health-care-administration-and-provider-resources/treatment-procedures-and-guidelines/emerging-public-health-issues/2019-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine/proof-of-vaccination. Yukon The Yukon vaccine pass is available at <(https://yukon.ca/vaccine-proof)https://yukon.ca/vaccine-proof.

transportation.text: International flights may land at Abbotsford (YXX/CYXX), Calgary (YYC/CYYC), Edmonton (YEG/CYEG), Fredericton (YFC/CYFC), Greater Moncton (YQM/CYQM), Halifax Stanfield (YHZ/CYHZ), Hamilton (YHM/CYHM), Kelowna (YLW/CYLW), Montreal-Trudeau (YUL/CYUL), Ontario-Thunder Bay (YQT/CYQT), Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier (YOW/CYOW), Québec City Jean Lesage (YQB/CYQB), Regina (YQR/CYQR), Saskatoon (YXE/CYXE), St. John's (YYT/CYYT), Stephenville (YJT/CYJT), Toronto Pearson (YYZ/CYYZ), Vancouver (YVR/CYVR), Victoria (YYJ/CYYJ), Waterloo (YKF/CYKF), Whitehorse (YXY/CYXY) and Winnipeg James Armstrong Richardson (YWG/CYWG) airports.   Passengers are subject to undergo temperature screening before departure or upon arrival; those with a temperature of 38 degrees Celsius (100.4 Fahrenheit) or higher after two separate tests will not be allowed to proceed to security screening, unless they present a medical certificate indicating that their elevated temperature is not due to COVID-19 (a negative COVID-19 certificate is not sufficient). Proof of full vaccination or a medical exemption is required for air passengers, both domestic and international.   WestJet and Air Canada Rouge have cancelled dozens of international flights due to staffing issues. Air Canada flights to Caribbean destinations are suspended from 24 January to 28 October.   Airline passengers, excluding children younger than two and those with disabilities, must wear face masks in transit, excluding masks with an exhalation valve, which are banned, and at screening checkpoints; people lacking protective gear or displaying COVID-19 symptoms like a fever or difficulty breathing will not be allowed to board. Entry to the terminals will be restricted to travellers only; people accompanying minors or individuals with disabilities are exempt.

declarationDocuments.text:
Travel (PLF) document
All travellers must submit contact and travel information in the ArriveCAN system within 72 hours prior to arrival. Fully vaccinated travelers must also enter their proof of vaccination. Travellers can upload their information online or via the ArriveCAN app.

entry.text: Land and ferry crossings into the United States (US) have reopened to fully vaccinated travellers.   All travellers aged 18 and older who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 will be permitted to enter Canada without quarantine or pre-departure and post-arrival testing. Foreign nationals aged 17 and under who are unvaccinated may be permitted entry provided they meet an exemption criteria. Foreign nationals who are immediate family members of Canadian citizens or permanent residents and who do not have or display any symptoms of COVID-19, as well as air crew, diplomats, seasonal workers, caregivers and international students are also exempt from the entry ban. Airline passengers will be permitted to transit through Canadian airports.

diseaseTesting.text: Before travel All inbound travellers aged 5 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR or equivalent test obtained within 72 hours prior to departure in order to enter Canada. Travellers may opt to take a professionally administered/observed rapid antigen test no more than one day before departure to Canada; the one-day window offers more flexibility than 24 hours and means that a rapid antigen test taken at any time on the day before a scheduled flight or entry via land or water will be valid. Previously recovered travellers may also opt to present a positive molecular test result taken between 10-180 days before entering Canada, provided they have no symptoms. Those without a negative result may face fines of up to CAD5,000 (USD4,005). Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated travellers ages five through 11 are exempt from pre-arrival testing if they are travelling with a fully vaccinated parent or guardian. Fully vaccinated travellers are exempt from pre-departure testing. Transit passengers are also exempt from testing so long as they do not leave designated transit lounges. A list of exemptions to testing is available at <(https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions>https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions. After arrival All unvaccinated travellers must undergo PCR or equivalent testing on day eight of their self-isolation period. A list of exemptions to testing is available at <(https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions>https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions. Upon arrival All unvaccinated travellers must undergo PCR or equivalent testing on arrival. Recently recovered travellers who can provide a positive COVID-19 test result within 10 to 180 days of arrival are exempt from testing on arrival. Fully vaccinated travellers may be subject to random testing upon arrival. Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated children ages five through 11 must undergo arrival testing if their parent or guardian is selected for randomised testing. A list of exemptions to testing is available at <(https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions'https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions. Designated overland crossing points with the United States (US) where tests can be administered are Douglas, British Columbia; Coutts, Alberta; Queenston-Lewiston Bridge, Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario; St Bernard de Lacolle (Highway 15), Quebec; St Stephen 3rd Bridge, New Brunswick; Ambassador Bridge, Windsor, Ontario; Blue Water Bridge, Point Edward, Ontario; Emerson West Lynne, Manitoba; Fort Erie (Peace Bridge), Ontario; Huntingdon, British Columbia; Lansdowne (Thousand Islands Bridge), Ontario; Pacific Highway, British Columbia; Rainbow Bridge, Niagara Falls, Ontario; St-Armand, Quebec; Stanstead (Route 55), Quebec and Windsor-Detroit Tunnel, Ontario.
diseaseTesting.when: Before travel, After arrival, Upon arrival
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, CRISPR, NGS, Antigen

tracingApplication.text: COVID Alert is an optional mobile app for the self-assessment of COVID-19 symptoms.

quarantineModality.text: All unvaccinated travellers aged 12 years and above must self-quarantine for 14 days. Unvaccinated air passengers must quarantine at a designated quarantine facility or another suitable location while they await the result of their on arrival test. Quarantine-free random on-arrival testing is in place and travellers under the age of 12 accompanied by fully vaccinated adults are no longer be subject to quarantine. Essential workers, those pre-approved for compassionate reasons and several other categories are exempt from the quarantine requirement. A list of exemptions to testing is available at <(https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions'https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions. Residents of Campobello Island, New Brunswick; Stewart, British Columbia; Northwest Angle, Minnesota; Point Roberts, Washington; and Hyder, Alaska, in the United States (US) are exempt from a mandatory 14-day self-quarantine.

mask.text: Voluntary face mask wearing is encouraged on ferries, trains and buses. Masks must be worn on flights.

diseaseVaccination.text: All travellers who were fully vaccinated against COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their arrival in Canada will be permitted to enter the country without having to self-quarantine, undergo pre-departure testing or post-arrival testing. Proof of vaccination must be submitted on the ArriveCan app prior to arrival. Vaccination as a requirement for entry applies to all foreign nationals aged 18 years and above; unvaccinated foreigners aged 17 and under may be permitted entry provided they meet an exemption criteria. All unvaccinated travellers aged 12 and above are subject to quarantine.   Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated foreign nationals will be denied entry unless they are a protected category.   Recently recovered travellers who can provide proof of a positive COVID-19 molecular test result, carried out at least 10 days and no more than 180 days before entering Canada, are exempt from on arrival testing.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 10 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: No national stay at home directive is in place, though social distancing is recommended; provinces and territories have issued their own directives. All vaccinated travellers are allowed entry without restriction.
